PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Anna S. F. N. Twistle
Address: Box 4, Portage, Sask.
Birthplace: Chicago, Ill., U.S.A.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1904
Where did you set up housekeeping? Grier, North Village, Wawasee
Where had you been living before that? U.S.A., Minnesota
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
How far was it to your nearest store? 6 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once in a month
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Coffee, tea, flour, dried beans, peas, onions, raisins, and dried apples.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Glenn, from the local mill at old Carlingford, Man., Wentworth County
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 pounds at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.65
How much did you use graham flour? About half, mother made brown bread
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes, How far away? 1 mile What year? 1904 earlier
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 85¢
What other grain products did you use? Oats, barley, and rice
Cornmeal? Yes, Whole Wheat? Yes, Rolled? Yes, Farina? Yes, Quinoa?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, we own about
How did you grind it? In the old-fashioned coffee mill

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Pork or beef.

Poultry, rabbit, game.

How did you get fresh meat? Killed own animals.

How often did you get fresh meat? Usually, depending on killed.

How did you preserve meat? Dried, salted, or smoked.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so, what year was it organized? 1920.

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Pheasant, chicken, rabbit, and turkey.

For how long? Short time each fall.

That part did fish play in the family diet? Very little.

Salt fish at the local store, and we drove 25 miles once in a summer to catch fish at Fish Lake near town on Montana side.

Can the fish fresh, cured, or canned? What was except over the fish?

Kinds? Salted, cooked, fresh, jackfish.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Some.
Peas? Yes. Corn? Beans? Yes. Saskatoon? No.
Other foods? Prune types are much better.
That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1920. Gooseberries and wild strawberries.
That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1920.
That year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1920.
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes, much.
Does this mean we need to?
To what extent? At least one quarter of what we eat.
Did you make your own vinegar? No, just bulk from the barrel at the grocer.
Melons came in barrels too. We always had to bring our own jugs.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Coal seems less dusty. Wood grown on our own farms now, which were scarce in the early years 1904 and on. Many use gasoline stoves in summer & some propane all year now. Therefore less burning fuel, wood, coal are used now.

Breakfast: Gravy Toast, fried eggs. Dinner: Mashed potatoes, carrots, white beans, baked apple pie.

Supper: Fried potatoes, baked beans, meat, lettuce & bread. Lemon curd, whole & dipped in honey & sugar.

Mother, Dad, 2 brothers, 1 sister, and myself.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No we never suffered hunger but our diet was restricted and we were so tired I meant potatoes that by spring we hunted dandelion leaves etc to make a pot of very welcome greens. And the first Rhubarb tasted wonderful and the finest wild strawberries blended with a few egg white cake mother used to make made a short cake in our oven could forget.

A few times we ran short of flour yeast and lived on flat buns and pancakes until the week long blizzards died down and we could struggle through the snow with a hand sleigh to get a fresh supply.

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We were never aware of hunger but our diet was restricted and we always had meat and vegetables. We had a good supply of vegetables and fruit and we always had enough to eat. We never went hungry.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The early times was a nightmare to pioneer women. They had as little to work with that the gangs of 30 men who came hard to cater to. One neighbor would take care of everyday work supply the busy ones. Others had all cooking equipment and dishes and went to help. As the local fruits had to be bought at such long distances, we had to go out and of course we could not get any vegetables had to be prepared each day. We often used to peel a pair of potatoes at 11 o'clock at night before them for breakfast.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

1912 boxes of apples came in very handy for the harvesting and harvest season.

1912 also saw corn, peas, and tomatoes start in cans.

1912 breakfast food partly took the place of our usual hot porridge.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

We had no way of disposing of our cream as we do now so we used to make butter and take it to town as barter for things we needed.

Nothing was graded. A raisin was a raisin, a prune just a prune whether large or small. Dried fruits kept well, freezing didn't seem to hurt them. Houses had to be banked carefully in the fall so our winter supply of potatoes etc. didn't freeze. Even then when an extra cold windy spell came, we rushed down cellar with poles and heated stones, lanterns etc. to keep things from freezing.
